File.Authors: N.S. CANTERAS, R.B. SIMERLY, AND L.W. SWANSON

Abstract.S: The organization of projections from the four parts of the ventromedial nucleus (VMH) and a ventrolaterally adjacent region tentatively identified as the tuberal nucleus (TU) have been analyzed with small injections of the anterograde axonal tracer Phaseolus uulgarisleucoagglutinin (PHA-L).
Extrinsic and intranuclear projections of each part of the VMH display clear quantitative differences, whereas the overall patterns of outputs are qualitatively similar.
Overall, the VMH establishes massive intrahypothalamic terminal fields in other parts of the medial zone, tending to avoid the periventricular and lateral zones.

The ventrolateral VMH is more closely related to other parts of the hypothalamus that also express gonadal steroid hormone receptors, including the medial preoptic, tuberal, and ventral premamillary nuclei, whereas other parts of the VMH are more closely related to the anterior hypothalamic and dorsal premammillary nuclei.
All parts of the VMH project to the zona incerta (including the A13 region) and parts of the midline thalamus, including the paraventricular and parataenial nuclei and nucleus reuniens.

The densest inputs to the septum are to the bed nuclei of the stria terminalis, where the ventrolateral and central VMH innervate the anteroventral and anterodorsal areas and transverse and interfascicular nuclei, whereas the anterior and dorsomedial VMH innervate the latter two.
The central, lateral, and medial amygdalar nuclei receive substantial inputs from various parts of the VMH.

Other regions of the telencephalon, including the nucleus accumbens and the piriform-amygdaloid, infralimbic, prelimbic, anterior cingulate, agranular insular, piriform, perirhinal, entorhinal, and postpiriform transition areas, also receive sparse inputs.
All parts of the VMH send a massive, topographically organized projection to the periaqueductal gray.

Other brainstem terminal fields include the superior colliculus, peripeduncular area, locus coeruleus, Barrington's nucleus, parabrachial nucleus, nucleus of the solitary tract, and the mesencephalic, pontine, gigantocellular, paragigantocellular, and parvicellular reticular nuclei.
The projections of the TU are similar to, and a subset of, those from the VMH and are thus not nearly as widespread as those from adjacent parts of the lateral hypothalamic area.
Because of these similarities, the TU may eventually come to be viewed most appropriately as the lateral component of the VMH itself.

The functional implications of the present findings are discussed in view of evidence that the VMH plays a role in the expression of ingestive, affective, and copulatory behaviors. 1994 Wiley-Liss, Inc.

Introduction.S: The ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus (VMH) has been in a variety Of ingestive, reproductive, and affective behaviors and in the physiological responses accomDanvinn them (Hetherimton and Ranson. 1942: Brooks et 91"-1946; and Brooks' 1965; Frohman and Bernardis' lg7" pfaff7 lg8O' Chateau et 1981; Perkins et al.3 1981; Tan and DampneY, lgS3; Fuchs et al., 1985a7b; Shimizu et a]., 1987; Cohen and Pfaff, 1992).

Current understanding of the axonal projections from the VMH that presumably mediate these functions is based mainly on two anterograde axonal tracer studies in the rat with the autoradiographic technique (Saper et al., 1976; Krieger et al., 1979).
The results indicated that five major pathways emerge from the nucleus.

A dorsal pathway ends in the thalamic paraventricular nucleus; a rostral pathway innervates parts of the telencephalon, including the bed nuclei of the stria terminalis (BST), lateral septal nucleus, substantia innominata, and central and medial nuclei of the amygdala, as well as the rostral end of the lateral hypothalamic area; a lateral pathway enters the supraoptic commissures; a ventrocaudal pathway innervates the mammillary complex, ventral tegmental area, and peripeduncular nucleus; and a dorsocaudal pathway innervates the posterior hypothalamic nucleus, periaqueductal gray, and locus coeruleus.
The present reexamination of VMH projections with the Phaseolus uulguris-leucoagglutinin (PHA-L) anterograde axonal tracer method was undertaken for several reasons.
First, the results of the autoradiographic studies mentioned above were not in complete agreement.

Specifically, Krieger et al. (1979) reported that the VMH has more widespread projections to the septal region (including the nucleus of the diagonal band) and amygdala (including the lateral nucleus) than was reported by Saper et al. (1976).

Second, Krieger et al. (1979) suggested that projections from all parts of the VMH are essentially similar, whereas Saper et al. (1976) indicated that outputs from the dorsomedial part are considerably more restricted than from the ventrolateral part.

Third, intrahypothalamic projections from the VMH were exceedingly difficult to characterize with the autoradiographic method because patterns of silver grains are detected and terminal fields along pathways, especially near injection sites, are difficult to identify with certainty.

Fourth, experience has shown that the PHA-L method is more sensitive than the autoradiographic method; that it labels axons, including terminal boutons and boutons-ofpassage, with the clarity of Golgi impregnations; and that very small injection sites may be produced and delineated accurately (Gerfen and Sawchenko, 1984).
Thus, it is an excellent method for examining intrahypothalamic terminal fields as well as others along pathways outside the hypothalamus.

Fifth, a great deal has been learned about the connections, parcellation, and chemoarchitecture of the basal forebrain since the 1970s, perhaps allowing for some reinterpretation of projections from the VMH itself.
The rat VMH has long been divided on cytoarchitectonic grounds into ventrolateral, central, and dorsomedial parts (Gurdjian, 1927).
Using both light and electron microscopy, Van Houten and Brawer (1978) identified and defined different histological regions within the VMH: anterior, middle, and posterior.

In coronal sections, the anterior region consists of a circular aggregate of densely packed perikarya, whereas the middle and posterior VMH are formed by two regional cell masses, dorsomedial and ventrolateral, separated by a diagonal cell-poor zone (Van Houten and Brawer, 1978).
It is now clear that the several parts of the VMH display very different patterns of gonadal steroid binding and receptor expression.

Thus, the ventrolateral part of the VMH (VMHvl) binds high levels of circulating estrogen (Pfaff and Keiner, 1973; Stumpf et al., 1975) and expresses abundant levels of estrogen receptor (Simerly et al., 1990).

Furthermore, the tuberal nucleus (TU) , which lies immediately lateral to the VMHvl, also binds estrogen (Pfaff and Keiner, 1973; Stumpf et al., 1975) and expresses the estrogen receptor (Simerly et al., 1990).
In contrast, androgen receptors are expressed throughout the VMH and in a more heterogeneous way in the TU (Simerly et al., 1990).

It has also been shown that neurons within theVMH (particularly the VMHv1) express high levels of progesterone receptor, preproenkephalin mRNA (coding for methionine and leucine enkephalin), and preprotachykinin mRNA (coding for substance P), and contain abundant oxytocin binding sites, thought to play a role in regulating feminine sexual behavior (Harlan et al., 1987; Romano et al., 1989a,b; Johnson et al., 1991).

This evidence lends support to the suggestion that different parts of the VMH may have somewhat different projections and raises the issue of projections from the estrogen-concentrating TU, which have never been examined.

The results of the present experiments confirm earlier results and also indicate that 1) the VMH has even broader projections, to the agranular and medial prefrontal cortical regions, for example; 2) the VMH establishes massive intrahypothalamic projections to the medial preoptic, anterior hypothalamic, and posterior hypothalamic nuclei but has much sparser inputs to the periventricular and lateral hypothalamic zones; 3) there are significant qualitative differences in projections from the dorsomedial, central, ventrolateral, and anterior parts of the VMH; and 4) projections from the TU resemble in most ways and are a subset of those from the VMHv1, and are thus not nearly as widespread as those from certain parts of the lateral hypothalamic area.

Methods.S: MATERIALS AND METHODS
Twenty adult male Sprague-Dawley rats (260-330 g) received a single injection of PHA-L (Vector Laboratories, Burlingame, CA) into the region of the VMH.
In addition, four other animals received a PHA-L deposit in the TU immediately adjacent to the VMHv1.

Each animal was anesthetized with tribromoethanol(O.25 gikg bw, dissolved in 9O:lO salineiethanol, viv), and a single iontophoretic injection of a 2.5% solution of PHA-L in 0.01 M sodium phosphate-buffered saline (pH 7.4) was made through a stereotaxically positioned glass micropipette (tip diameter 10 Fm) by applying a +5 pA current pulsed at 7-second intervals provided by a constant-current source (Midgard Electronics model CS3) for a period of 15 minutes.
Postinjection survival times for all experiments ranged from 14 to 18 days.
The animals were perfused and the brains were processed according to procedures described in detail elsewhere (Canteras et al., 1992a).

Briefly, each animal was deeply anesthetized with tribromoethanol and perfused transcardially with a solution of 4.0% paraformaldehyde in 0.1 M sodium borate buffer at pH 9.5; the brains were removed immediately and postfixed overnight in the same fixative containing 10% sucrose.

Three series of 30-pm-thick frozen sections were cut in the frontal plane on a sliding microtome and collected at the following frequencies: one in ten through the olfactory bulbs and forebrain rostral to the vascular organ of the lamina terminalis; one in four through the hypothalamus and rostral half of the midbrain; and one in ten through the caudal midbrain, hindbrain, and rostral spinal cord.
Additional sections were collected through levels containing the tuberal region of the hypothalamus and quick stained for confirmation of injection site location (see Simerly and Swanson, 1988).
One complete series of sections was processed for immunohistochemistry with an antiserum directed against PHA-L (Dako Laboratories) at a dilution of 1: 1,000.

The antigenantibody complex was localized by using a variation of the avidin-biotin complex system (ABC; Hsu and Raine, 1981; Hsu et al., 1981), with a commercially available kit (ABC Elite Kit; Vector Laboratories).
The sections were mounted on gelatin-coated slides and treated with osmium tetroxide to enhance visibility of the reaction product.
Slides were then dehydrated and coverslipped with DPX.
An adjacent series was always stained with thionin to serve as a reference series for cytoarchitectonic purposes.
Sections were examined with a Leitz Laborlux D microscope with both brightand darkfield illumination.

PHA-Llabeled cells in the injection sites, as well as the distribution of anterogradely labeled fibers, were plotted with the aid of a camera lucida on maps prepared from adjacent Nisslstained sections.
For purposes of illustration, the distribution of anterogradely labeled fibers was transferred onto a series of standard drawings of the rat brain (Swanson, 1992).

In the process of transposing our results onto standard drawings, as a first step, we tried to match as closely as possible the actual section to be represented with the corresponding section in the atlas (Swanson, 19921, based on a careful observation of cytoarchitectonic features.

In order to achieve the most accurate representation, once the correct standard section was chosen for a given pathway or terminal field, in addition to the maps prepared with the aid of the camera lucida, constant observation of the actual material was accomplished with a Leitz Laborlux D microscope while plotting the distribution of anterogradely labeled fibers onto the standard drawing.
Unless otherwise indicated, parcellation of the rat brain follows Swanson (1992).

Results.S: RESULTS
Injection sites
The parameters used for iontophoretic injections of PHA-L resulted in very discrete injection sites, usually with hundreds of clearly labeled perikarya.
Cells labeled with PHA-L were almost entirely confined to the VMH in 16 experiments.
Of these, four injections were limited almost entirely to the VMHv1, five to the VMHdm, two to the VMHc, and one to the VMHa.
One injection involved both the VMHa and rostral parts of the VMHdm and VMHc, and three injections were centered in the VMHvl with a substantial number of labeled cells in the VMHdm and VMHc.

The appearance and location of PHA-L-labeled cells for representative injections localized primarily to the anterior, dorsomedial, and ventrolateral parts of the VMH are shown in Figure 1, and the distribution of labeled neurons in two of the experiments centered in the VMHc is illustrated in Figure 2.

In addition, four animals received PHA-L deposits centered in the TU, immediately adjacent to the VMH; in two experiments, labeled cells seemed confined to the TU, and in the other two, the injection also involved a number of cells in the VMHvl.
Projections from the ventromedial nucleus
The exact distribution pattern of labeled fibers was reliably correlated with the part of the VMH containing the most labeled neurons.
However, in all experiments with PHA-L deposits centered in the VMH, regardless of their precise location, labeled fibers followed the same basic routes.
A detailed account of these pathways will be given as we describe our results on projections from the ventrolateral part of the VMH.
For the terminology used to describe labeled axons, see Risold et al. (1994).
Projections from the ventrolateral part of the VMH.

TTE.S: In four experiments, the PHA-L injection labeled neurons confined almost entirely to the ventrolateral part of the VMH, although different injections labeled different rostrocaudal levels of this structure (rostral half, experiment VMHvl 15; middle third, experiment VMHvl 10; caudal half, experiment VMHvl29; caudal two-thirds, experiment VMHvl 25).

In all of these cases, a very similar pattern of anterogradely labeled fibers was observed, and of these, we chose experiment VMHvl25 (Figs. lC,C , 3) as a prototype to illustrate our results because the injection here labeled the most extensive population of cells in the VMHv1.

Labeled axons from the VMHvl may be divided into an ascending group that innervates targets rostral to the nucleus in the diencephalon and telencephalon and a descending group to the caudal hypothalamus and brainstem.

Apart from projections to other structures, it is important to point out that a large number of labeled boutons was also observed within the ventrolateral part of the VMH itself, whereas the other parts of the nucleus contained only very sparse anterograde labeling (Fig. 3K-0).
Ascending projections.

The greater part of the labeled fibers from the VMHvl course rostrally through the medial zone of the hypothalamus and medial portions of the medial forebrain bundle, whereas a smaller group of axons was also observed ascending through rostral parts of the zona incerta just dorsal to the hypothalamus.
Many fibers entering medial portions of the medial forebrain bundle at the tuberal level of the hypothalamus appear to provide significant inputs to the TU (Fig. 3L-0).

It is important to remark here that only a small number of fibers from the VMHvl enter the periventricular zone where, at tuberal levels, only a few labeled boutons were observed within the arcuate and periventricular nuclei (Fig. 3K-0).

Rostral to the tuberal level, some axons ascending through the medial forebrain bundle merge with another massive contingent of fibers that leave the VMHvl to ascend through the medial zone of the hypothalamus where, at the anterior hypothalamic level, they supply relatively strong inputs to the retrochiasmatic area, the anterior hypothalamic nucleus, and the subparaventricular zone, including regions around the suprachiasmatic nucleus (Fig. 3G-L).

Rostral zones of the central part of the anterior hypothalamic nucleus receive a strikingly dense plexus of fibers from the VMHv1, a plexus that also extends into the adjacent region around the suprachiasmatic nucleus (Figs. 3H,I, 7).

It is important to point out that a large number of fibers were also seen passing through the anterior part of the anterior hypothalamic nucleus, although they have the appearance of fibersof-passage with very few branches and boutons (Figs. 3 G J , 7).
Just dorsal to the anterior hypothalamic nucleus, a dense plexus of fibers also appears to innervate the perifornical region (Fig. 3HJ).
Compared to the dense inputs to the medial zone, cell groups within the periventricular zone at the anterior hypothalamic level appear to receive much sparser inputs.

A moderate number of fibers was observed in the anterior parvicellular part of the paraventricular nucleus, and only scattered labeled axons were found throughout the other parvicellular parts; only occasional anterograde labeling was found within the magnocellular division (Figs. 3G-L, 7).

Proceeding rostrally, a large number of fibers from the VMHvl reach the preoptic region, where they appear to provide a dense input to undifferentiated parts of the medial preoptic area and the lateral part of the medial preoptic nucleus, whereas only a few appear to project to or through the medial and central parts of this nucleus, as well as the anteroventral periventricular and median preoptic nuclei (Figs. 3D-H, 7).

From the injection site, a number of labeled axons take a dorsal course, and, whereas the vast majority extend caudally through the posterior hypothalamic nucleus (as described below), some of these fibers continue rostrally through rostral parts of the zona incerta, where they provide inputs to the region of the A13 dopaminergic cell group and rostral pole of the zona incerta (Fig. 3K-M).

Furthermore, a number of fibers from the VMHvl that ascend through the hypothalamus and zona incerta may also enter the thalamus, where they appear to innervate the nucleus reuniens, as well as the paraventricular and parataenial nuclei (Fig. 3G-M).
A group of ascending fibers from the VMHvl provides rather massive inputs to the BST and, to a lesser extent, the lateral septa1 nucleus and caudal pole of the nucleus accumbens.

At preoptic levels, these axons leave the hypothalamus by taking either a dorsolateral route toward caudal regions of the BST (Fig. 3F-H) or a dorsal route rostral to the anterior commissure (Fig. 3D).

Within the posterior division of the BST, the transverse and interfascicular nuclei are filled with a dense plexus of fibers, whereas the principal nucleus appears to receive only a very sparse input (Fig. 3G,H).

At this level, a contingent of labeled axons enters the substantia innominata (in the ansa peduncularis) or, to a much lesser extent, the stria terminalis, and thus gains access to the amygdala and adjacent cortical areas, as described below (Fig. 3G,H).

Within the anterior division of the BST, the VMHvl supplies dense inputs to the anterodorsal and anteroventral areas, whereas only caudal zones of the anterolateral area appear to receive a significant number of fibers (Fig. 3D-F).

Furthermore, it is important to remark here that the parastrial nucleus of the preoptic region, which lies immediately adjacent to the anteroventral area of the BST, tends to be almost completely avoided by anterogradely-labeled axons from the VMHvl (Fig. 3D-F).

In contrast to the BST, the lateral septa1 nucleus receives a much sparser contingent of fibers, which appear to innervate mainly the rostra1 two-thirds of the ventral and intermediate parts of the nucleus (Fig. 3B-F).
Finally, some labeled fibers continue rostrally from the lateral septa1 nucleusand appear to end in the infralimbic, prelimbic, and anterior cingulate areas (Fig. 3A).
Ascending fibers from the VMHvlalso provide inputs to several parts of the amygdala.
Most labeled axons from the injection site reach the amygdala through two distinct pathways, the stria terminalis and ansa peduncularis, with the latter representing by far the main route.
Two distinct bundles of labeled fibers project through the ansa peduncularis to the amygdala.

The first consists of fibers that leave the posterior subdivision of the BST and course through the substantia innominata, where they provide a significant number of labeled boutons before entering the amygdala (Fig. 3G-J).
The second consists of labeled axons running through the ipsilateral ventral supraoptic commissure system (see Magoun and Ranson, 1942; Figs. 3L,M, 8).
In addition, a smaller number of fibers may reach the amygdala by traveling directly through the lateral hypothalamic area.

The medial and capsular parts of the central nucleus, as well as the lateral nucleus, of the amygdala receive significant inputs from the VMHv1, which also seems to provide much sparser inputs to several other amygdaloid nuclei (Fig. 3G-R).
Furthermore, some fibers coursing through the amygdala were followed to the piriform area, perirhinal area, postpiriform transition area, and lateral part of the entorhinal area (Fig. 3G-S).
Descending projections.

Labeled fibers descending from the injection site follow three main routes: 1) the medial hypothalamus and medial forebrain bundle; 2) the midbrain periventricular system; and 3) the ventral supraoptic commissure system.

One group of axons from the VMHvl extends caudally through the medial hypothalamus and the medial forebrain bundle, providing sparse inputs to the ventral premammillary nucleus and to the mammillary complex, but clearly tend to avoid the dorsal premammillary nucleus (Fig. 3P-S).
In the mammillary complex, sparse fibers were seen in the medial and lateral parts of the supramammillary nucleus and in the capsule surrounding the medial mammillary nucleus (Fig. 3R,S).
Some fibers in this pathway continue through the ventral tegmental area and appear to end in the rostral linear, central linear, and interfascicular nuclei of the raphe (Fig. 3S-W).

In addition, some fibers from the VMHvl descending through the medial forebrain bundle and medial hypothalamus may take a dorsolateral route and enter the zona incerta, where they extend caudally to the region of the peripeduncular nucleus and merge with other descending fibers from the VMHvl that course along the ventral supraoptic commissure and the parvicellular part of the subparafascicular nucleus, as described below (Fig. 3M-TI.
A majority of descending fibers from the injection site take a dorsal route and extend caudally through the posterior hypothalamic nucleus into the central gray.

Just dorsal to the VMH, some of these fibers pass through the dorsomedial nucleus, where they seem to provide inputs chiefly to the rostral pole of the anterior part while tending to avoid the posterior part of the nucleus (Fig. 3M-0).
A moderate number of fibers passing through the posterior hypothalamic nucleus take a lateral course and enter the magnocellular part of the subparafascicular nucleus (Fig. 3Q).

These fibers extend caudally through the parvicellular part of the subparafascicular nucleus, where they generate a moderate number of boutons, and, in the region of the peripeduncular nucleus, merge with fibers coursing through the zona incerta and ventral supraoptic commissures (Fig. 3R-T).

In addition, some labeled fibers from the VMHvl following the caudal route through the posterior hypothalamic nucleus and central gray split off to enter the lateral habenula, pretectal region, and several thalamic nuclei, including the lateral dorsal nucleus, lateral posterior nucleus, central lateral nucleus, intermediodorsal nucleus, medial part of the mediodorsal nucleus, posterior paraventricular nucleus, posterior complex, reticular nucleus, lateral geniculate body, and medial geniculate body (Fig. 3N-U).
Notably, the latter three parts of the thalamus also appear to receive a few axons coursing through the zona incerta and ventral supraoptic commissures (Fig. 30-U).
The entire rostrocaudal extent of the periaqueductal gray contained a large number of anterogradely labeled fibers from the VMHv1.
However, the pattern of anterograde labeling changed systematically along the rostrocaudal axis (Fig. 3R-Y).
Thus, at the rostralmost level, fibers coursing through the periaqueductal gray form a moderately dense terminal field in a region adjacent to the subcommissural organ (Fig 3R).
It is important to note here that this region contains a relatively distinct group of medium-sized neurons referred to by Paxinos and Watson (1986) as the precommissural nucleus (Fig. 3R).
Labeled fibers extend caudally, mainly through dorsal and dorsolateral regions of the periaqueductal gray, where they provide a moderate number of terminals (Fig. 3SU).

At the level of the oculomotor nucleus, two focal bands of anterogradely labeled fibers were observed passing through dorsal and ventrolateral regions of the periaqueductal gray; these fibers display very few boutons-of-passage and varicosities, and because of this morphology, most of them are probably fibers-of-passage (Fig. 3V,W).

The peripheral half of the dorsolateral part of the periaqueductal gray at this level, which seems to correspond to a region delineated by very low levels of cytochrome oxidase staining (Conti et al., 19881, was devoid of anterograde labeling (Fig. 3V,W).

At caudal levels of the periaqueductal gray, fibers coursing through the midbrain periventricular system form a very dense terminal field in ventrolateral regions of the periaqueductal gray, dorsal to the laterodorsal tegmental nucleus (Fig. 3X,Y).
A number of labeled fibers coursing through the midbrain periventricular system enter the superior colliculus and mesencephalic reticular nucleus (Fig. 3s-X).
Within the former, labeled fibers appear to innervate mainly the deepest layer of gray matter.

In addition, at the caudal pole of the periaqueductal gray, a group of labeled fibers appears to leave the ventrolateral region and enter the cuneiform nucleus, and to a much lesser extent the parabrachial nucleus (Fig. 3X,Y).

A small group of labeled axons extends caudally from the periaqueductal gray into the pontine central gray, where they seem to provide a sparse input to Barrington's nucleus, and occasional fibers were also observed within the borders of the locus coeruleus (Fig. 32).
In addition, a few of these fibers arch laterally to enter the parabrachial nucleus (Fig. 32).
Finally, a significant number of fibers descending from the VMHvl join the ipsilateral ventral supraoptic commissures and continue dorsocaudally between the optic tract and cerebral peduncle.
A few of these fibers appear to end in the ventral part of the lateral geniculate body and caudal parts of the reticular nucleus of the thalamus (Fig. 3P-R).

However, a majority continue farther caudally and, at the level of the peripeduncular nucleus, merge with other descending fibers coursing through the zona incerta and the parvicellular part of the subparafascicular nucleus, providing dense inputs to the peripedundular nucleus, caudal regions of the parvicellular part of the subparafascicular nucleus, and adjacent regions of the mesencephalic reticular nucleus (Fig. 3s-U).
Some fibers extend caudally, where they join a group of descending fibers that enter the mesencephalic reticular nucleus by coursing through the midbrain periventricular system.
They provide a sparse terminal field in caudal regions of the mesencephalic reticular nucleus, just ventral to the deep gray layer of the superior colliculus (Fig. 3V,W).
Caudal to this level, labeled fibers were only rarely observed in the reticular core of the brainstem.

Thus, a very few fibers could also be traced to rostral and caudal parts of the pontine reticular (Fig.3X-Z), magnocellular reticular, paragigantocellular reticular, and parvicellular reticular nuclei (not illustrated).
In addition, occasional anterograde labeling was also observed within the borders of the nucleus of the solitary tract (not illustrated).
Crossed projections.
Although the projections of the VMHvl are largely ipsilateral, some fibers cross the midline to the contralateral side.
In general, the contralateral projection is a mirror image of the ipsilateral projection, but much less dense.

In the forebrain, labeled fibers cross the midline dorsal to the caudal third of the third ventricle (Fig. 30,P), through the supraoptic commissures (Fig. 3I,J), and, to a lesser extent, through the anterior commissure (Fig. 3F).
Curiously, a few axons were seen passing to the other side sandwiched between the internal lamina of the median eminence and the ependymal wall of the third ventricle (Fig. 3K-0).

Results.S: Some of the fibers crossing through the supraoptic commissures enter the ventral supraoptic commissure system, providing sparse contralateral inputs to the same regions in the amygdala and brainstem.
In the brainstem, a majority of the fibers cross the midline dorsal to the cerebral aqueduct (Fig. 3T-Y).
Projections from the dorsomedial part of the VMH.

TTE.S: In five experiments,the PHA-L deposit labeled neurons that were fairly confined to the dorsomedial part of the VMH (VMHdm).

Although each of these experiments involved different rostrocaudal levels of the VMHdm (rostral third, experiment VMHro 3; middle third, experiments VMHdm 7 and VMHdm 8; caudal third, experiments VMHdm 10 and VMHdm 14), a very similar pattern of anterogradely labeled fibers was observed.
Experiment VMHdm 8 (Figs. 1B,B , 4) was chosen as a prototype to illustrate our results.

In this experiment, as well as in all the other cases with an injection centered in the VMHdm, a large number of labeled boutons was found throughout the dorsomedial part and, to a lesser extent, in the central part of the VMH, whereas the ventrolateral and anterior parts of the nucleus contained only a few anterogradely labeled fibers (Fig. 4F-J).

From the injection site, ascending fibers course along the same routes as described for the VMHvl, although a much smaller group of labeled fibers was found extending along the medial forebrain bundle, and they appear to provide only a sparse input to the TU adjacent to the VMHvl (Fig. 4G-J).

At the anterior hypothalamic level, many anterogradely labeled fibers were distributed throughout the medial zone of the hypothalamus, and they supply dense inputs to the anterior hypothalamic nucleus, retrochiasmatic area, and subparaventricular zone (including the perisuprachiasmatic region; Figs. 4C-G, 7).

In contrast to what was described above for the VMHvI, axons from the VMHdm form a strikingly dense terminal field in the posterior part, as well as rostral zones of the anterior part of the anterior hypothalamic nucleus (Figs. 4C-G, 7).
Furthermore, at this level, the perifornical region also appears to receive a dense input from the VMHdm (Fig. 4D-F).
In contrast to these dense inputs to the medial zone of the hypothalamus, cell groups in the periventricular zone appear to receive a much sparser input (Figs. 4CJ, 7).
In particular, only a small contingent of fibers from the VMHdm reaches the preoptic region, in sharp contrast to what was described for the VMHvl (Figs. 4A-C, 7).

A number of fibers from the VMHdm also course through rostral parts of the zona incerta, where they appear to provide inputs to the A13 dopaminergic cell group and rostral pole of the zona incerta (Fig. 4F-H).

A group of fibers ascending from the injection site may also enter the thalamus, where they supply a moderate number of labeled boutons particularly to a dorsal zone in the rostral pole of the nucleus reuniens (Fig. 4D) and rostral parts of the paraventricular nucleus (Fig. 4D,E).
Ascending fibers from the VMHdm also project to several telencephalic targets, following the same pathways described for experiment VMHvl 25.
Thus, the posterior division of the BST contained a moderate to dense plexus of labeled fibers within the transverse and interfascicular nuclei (Fig. 4C).
In contrast, only a few axons from the VMHdm innervate the anterior division of the BST, where scattered fibers were distributed mainly within the anterodorsal and anteroventral areas (Fig. 4A,B).

The lateral septal nucleus contained a small number of labeled fibers distributed mainly within the intermediate and ventral parts (Fig. 4A,B), although occasional anterograde labeling was also observed within the dorsal part of the lateral septal nucleus as well as in the medial septal and septofimbrial nuclei.

A very small number of fibers from injections centered in the VMHdm may also project to the nucleus accumbens and medial prefrontal cortex (not illustrated), where anterograde labeling was reliably found in the infralimbic, prelimbic, and anterior cingulate areas.
The VMHdm also provides a significant input to the amygdala that differs from VMHvl inputs in several ways.
The central nucleus receives somewhat fewer anterogradely labeled fibers from the VMHdm, and they are distributed within the medial and capsular parts of the nucleus (Fig. 4D-I).

Like the VMHv1, the VMHdm projects densely to the lateral nucleus (Fig. 4I,J), and also appears to provide denser inputs to the anterodorsal part of the medial nucleus, the posterior part of the basomedial nucleus, the piriform-amygdaloid area, and caudal regions of the lateral zone of the posterior part of the cortical nucleus (Fig. 4F-L).

Furthermore, some fibers could also reliably be traced throughout the entire rostrocaudal extent of the piriform area and endopiriform nucleus as well as through the perirhinal, postpiriform transition, and entorhinal areas (Fig. 4A-N).
Like theVMHvl, fibers from the VMHdm descend through 1) the medial hypothalamus and medial forebrain bundle, 2) the midbrain periventricular system, and 3) the ventral supraoptic commissure system.

From the VMHdm, a number of labeled fibers descend through the medial zone of the hypothalamus and medial forebrain bundle, providing a moderate input to the dorsal premammillary nucleus as well as sparse inputs to the capsule surrounding the medial mammillary nucleus; notably, they tend to avoid the ventral premammillary nucleus (Fig. 4K-M).

Farther caudally, only a few labeled fibers could be traced through the ventral tegmental area, and they seem to provide very sparse inputs to the rostral linear, central linear, and interfascicular nuclei of the raphe (Fig. 4M-Q).

In addition, a small number of fibers coursing through this pathway enter the zona incerta and appear to end in the ventral part of the lateral geniculate body, the caudal zones of the reticular nucleus of the thalamus, and the region of the peripeduncular nucleus, where they merge with other descending fibers coursing through the ventral supraoptic commissure and parvicellular part of the subparafascicular nucleus (Fig. 41-N).
The vast majority of fibers descending from the VMHdm enter the posterior hypothalamic nucleus and extend caudally into the central gray.

It is important to remark here that, while coursing dorsally toward the posterior hypothalamic nucleus, labeled fibers from the VMHdm tend to avoid the dorsomedial nucleus, which appears to receive only a very sparse input (Fig. 4H-J).
In contrast to what was described for the VMHvl, only a few axons coursing through the posterior hypothalamic area arch laterally to extend caudally through the subparafascicular nucleus (Fig. 4K-N).

In addition, like the VMHv1, descending fibers from the VMHdm coursing through the rostral end of the midbrain periventricular system may also provide sparse inputs to several parts of the thalamus (including the lateral habenula) and some pretectal nuclei (Fig. 41-01.
The pattern of inputs to the periaqueductal gray from the VMHdm was quite different from that described for the VMHvl.

At rostral levels, the VMHdm provides a considerably more dense terminal field in a region adjacent to the subcommissural organ that includes the precommissural nucleus of Paxinos and Watson, (1986; Fig. 4L).

In contrast to the VMHv1, at the level of the Edinger-Westphal nucleus rostral to the oculomotor nucleus (Fig. 4N,O), the VMHdm supplies a strikingly dense input to dorsal and dorsolateral regions of the periaqueductal gray.
Proceeding caudally, there is a slight decrease in the number of anterogradely labeled fibers, and they continue chiefly through dorsal and dorsolateral regions of the periaqueductal gray.

At the level of the oculomotor nucleus, anterograde labeling tended to fall off strikingly in the peripheral half of the dorsolateral region, which seems to correspond to a region of the periaqueductal gray characterized by very low levels of cytochrome oxidase staining (Conti et al., 1988; Fig. 4P,Q).

At more caudal levels, anterograde labeling in the periaqueductal gray was distributed dorsal to the laterodorsal tegmental nucleus (Fig. 4R,S) in a pattern that was similar to but less dense than that described for the VMHvl.
A number of fibers coursing through the midbrain periventricular system from the VMHdm enter the superior colliculus and, to a much lesser extent, the mesencephalic reticular nucleus (Fig. 4M-R).
In addition, at caudal levels of the periaqueductal gray, a group of fibers projects to the cuneiform and parabrachial nuclei (Fig. 4R,S).
Only a few axons extend caudal to the periaqueductal gray into the pontine central gray, where they appear to provide sparse inputs to Barrington s nucleus and the locus coeruleus (Fig. 4T).
In contrast to the VMHvl, only a small number of axons from the VMHdm extend caudally through the ventral supraoptic commissures to provide a sparse input to the peripeduncular nucleus (Fig. 4N,O).

Fibers coursing through this pathway at the level of the peripeduncular nucleus join other descending fibers in the parvicellular part of the subparafascicular nucleus and zona incerta and together descend through the reticular core of the brainstem (Fig. 4N-T).

The overall distribution of labeled fibers within the pons and medulla is similar to that described above for the VMHvl, where occasional anterograde labeling was observed within rostral and caudal parts of the pontine reticular nucleus (Fig. 4R-T), within the magnocellular reticular nucleus, as well as within the borders of the nucleus of the solitary tract (not illustrated).

Results.S: Finally, some axons from the VMHdm cross the midline in the same pathways described for the VMHvl and provide sparse inputs to essentially the same targets as on the ipsilateral side.
Curiously, the density of crossed fibers is greater in the midbrain and pons than in the forebrain.

TTE.S: Projections from the central part of the VMH.

As shown in Figure 2, two experiments labeled neurons that were fairly confined to the central part of the VMH (VMHc), and each experiment involved different rostrocaudal levels of this structure (rostral half, experiment VMHdm 6; caudal half, experiment VMHvl22).

In both of these cases, a very similar pattern of anterogradely labeled fibers was observed, and there was an interesting blending of certain features just described for the ventrolateral and dorsomedial parts.

In both of these experiments, a large number of labeled boutons was observed throughout the VMHc and, to a lesser extent in the VMHdm, whereas the ventrolateral and anterior parts of the nucleus contained a much smaller number of anterogradely labeled fibers.
Ascending projections from the VMHc to the hypothalamus, zona incerta, and thalamus were very similar to those described for the VMHdm.

Thus, at the anterior hypothalamic level, anterograde labeling observed in experiments involving the VMHc presented the same pattern of distribution to the anterior hypothalamic nucleus, subparaventricular zone (including regions around the suprachiasmatic nucleus), retrochiasmatic area, and perifornical area.

However, as compared to the VMHdm, somewhat more axons from the VMHc enter the periventricular zone, providing somewhat denser inputs to the parvicellular division of the paraventricular nucleus, the periventricular nuclei, and the arcuate nucleus.

The preoptic region also receives only a sparse contingent of axons from the VMHc, and they are distributed mainly within undifferentiated parts of the medial preoptic area and the lateral part of the medial preoptic nucleus.
Furthermore, the distribution of ascending fibers to the zona incerta and thalamus was very similar to that described for the VMHdm.
Thus, the region of the A13 dopaminergic cell group and the rostral pole of the zona incerta receive a moderate projection from the VMHc.

And, in the thalamus, ascending fibers from the VMHc also form a well-defined terminal field in rostral parts of the paraventricular nucleus and the dorsal part of the rostral pole of the nucleus reuniens.
Compared to the VMHdm, ascending fibers from the VMHc provide a denser input to the septal region, which is similar to the projection described for the VMHv1.
Within the posterior division of the BST, the transverse and interfascicular nuclei contained a dense plexus of labeled fibers, whereas the principal nucleus appeared to be only sparsely innervated.

The anterior division of the BST also receives a dense plexus of labeled fibers that is mainly distributed within the anterodorsal and anteroventral areas, whereas they clearly tend to avoid the anterolateral area.

As with the VMHvl, the VMHc also appears to provide inputs to the lateral septal nucleus, which contained a plexus of fibers mainly distributed within the rostral twothirds of the ventral and intermediate parts.
Rostral to the septal region, a few axons from the VMHc could also be traced to the nucleus accumbens, as well as to the infralimbic, prelimbic, and anterior cingulate areas.
Injections centered in the VMHc also label inputs to several parts of the amygdala, with the axons following the same routes as described for the VMHv1.

And it is important to emphasize here that, similar to what was described for the VMHvl, labeled fibers from VMHc injections course through and innervate the substantia innominata before reaching the amygdala.
The same zones of the medial and capsular parts of the central nucleus contained a moderately dense plexus of labeled fibers after injections in the VMHvl and VMHc.

Ventral regions of the lateral nucleus of the amygdala also contained a dense plexus of fibers from the VMHc, which also projects sparsely to other nuclei that are significantly innervated by the VMHdm; these include the anterodorsal part of the medial nucleus, the posterior part of the basomedial nucleus, the piriform-amygdaloid area, and caudal regions of the lateral zone of the posterior part of the cortical nucleus.
Furthermore, a few anterogradely labeled fibers also reach the endopiriform nucleus, as well as the piriform, perirhinal, entorhinal, and postpiriform transition areas.
Descending axons from VMHc injections follow the same pathways as described for other parts of the VMH.

Thus, a group of fibers descends through the medial zone of the hypothalamus and medial forebrain bundle to provide sparse inputs to the dorsal and ventral premammillary nuclei, to the supramammillary nucleus, and to the capsule surrounding the medial mammillary nucleus.
Some of these fibers also continue through the ventral tegmental area to innervate the rostral linear, central linear, and interfascicular nuclei of the raphe.

A majority of the fibers descending from the VMHc course dorsally to enter the posterior hypothalamic nucleus near the central gray, whereas only a sparse contingent of descending fibers extend through the supraoptic commissure system or the route through the subparafascicular nucleus, as described above for the VMHdm.

However, in contrast to the VMHdm, a moderate number of fibers in this dorsal route to the midbrain periventricular system pass through and provide a significant input to the anterior and ventral parts of the dorsomedial nucleus, whereas fibers tend to avoid the posterior part of the nucleus.
Furthermore, a small contingent of axons coursing through the periventricular pathway also projects to the thalamus in a fashion similar to that described above for the VMHvl and VMHdm.
The pattern of projections to the rostral half of the periaqueductal gray closely resembles that described for the VMHdm.
Thus, at rostral levels, a dense terminal field was observed in the region adjacent to the subcommissural organ.

Proceeding caudally, the VMHc (like the VMHdm) supplies a dense input to dorsal and dorsolateral regions of the periaqueductal gray at the level of the EdingerWestphal nucleus, rostral to the oculomotor nucleus.

However, in contrast to the VMHdm, fibers from the VMHc at the level of the oculomotor nucleus completely avoid the peripheral half of the dorsolateral region of the periaqueductal gray, and two focal bands of anterograde labeling were observed in the dorsal and ventrolateral parts of the periaqueductal gray, like that shown for the VMHv1.
And, at caudal levels of the periaqueductal gray, anterograde labeling was also distributed dorsal to the laterodorsal tegmental nucleus.
Only a small number of fibers extend caudally into the pontine central gray, where they present the same pattern of distribution as that described for the VMHvl and VMHdm.

Furthermore, axons from the VMHc coursing through the midbrain periventricular system may end in the superior colliculus, cuneiform nucleus, and, to a much lesser extent, the mesencephalic reticular and parabrachial nuclei.

As mentioned above, only a few axons from the VMHc extend caudally through the ventral supraoptic commissure system, zona incerta, and subparafascicular nucleus, providing sparse inputs to the peripeduncular nucleus and adjacent regions of the mesencephalic reticular nucleus, similar to what was described above for the VMHdm.

Finally, as for other parts of the VMH, some of these fibers may also extend caudally through the reticular core of the brainstem, where occasional anterograde labeling was found in the rostral and caudal parts of the pontine reticular nucleus and in the magnocellular reticular nucleus.

The projections from the VMHc are largely ipsilateral, although a number of fibers cross the midline in the same pathways described for other parts of the VMH, providing a much less dense contralateral projection to essentially the same targets as on the ipsilateral side.

Results.S: Projections from the anterior part of the VMH.

TTE.S: The injection site in experiment VMHro 4 was limited almost entirely to the anterior part of the VMH (VMHa; Fig.lA,A').
The distribution pattern of anterogradely labeled fibers in this case, which is summarized in Figure 5, was somewhat distinct from other experiments involving different parts of the VMH.

These results were partly confirmed in another experiment (VMHro 51, where the PHA-L deposit labeled many cells in the anterior part as well as rostral zones of the dorsomedial and central parts of the VMH .

From the injection site, a majority of the labeled fibers ascend through the medial zone of the hypothalamus, where, at anterior hypothalamic levels, they appear to provide significant inputs to the anterior hypothalamic nucleus, retrochiasmatic area, and subparaventricular zone (including the perisuprachiasmatic region; Fig. 5D-F).

Fibers from the VMHa form a particularly dense terminal field in the ventral zone of the central part of the anterior hypothalamic nucleus, just dorsal to the anterior part, which, however, was also traversed by a number of labeled axons with the appearance of fibers-of-passage (Fig. 5D-F).

In contrast to the dense innervation of structures in the medial zone of the anterior hypothalamic level, only a few axons project to the periventricular zone, where the parvicellular division of the paraventricular nucleus as well as the anterior and intermediate periventricular nuclei appear to receive only very sparse inputs (Fig. 5E,F).
Compared to other parts of the VMH, fibers ascending from the VMHa appear to provide sparser inputs to the perifornical region at anterior hypothalamic levels (Fig. 5E,F).

Proceeding rostrally, the preoptic region receives only a small contingent of ascending fibers from the VMHa, where, as described for other parts of the VMH, they were mainly distributed within undifferentiated parts of the medial preoptic area and the lateral part of the medial preoptic nucleus (Fig. 5B-D).
In addition, a group of ascending fibers from the VMHa projects to the rostral pole of the zona incerta and to the thalamus.

Although the rostral pole of the zona incerta contained a very small number of fibers (Fig. 5F), a very dense terminal field was limited to the ventral part of the rostral pole of the nucleus reuniens (Fig. 5E) in sharp contrast to projections described from other parts of the VMH.

Furthermore, ascending fibers from the VMHa appear to provide significant inputs to rostral parts of the paraventricular nucleus along with sparse inputs to other neighboring thalamic nuclei (Fig. 5D-F).
Anterogradely labeled fibers from the VMHa could also be followed to several telencephalic regions in a somewhat similar way to projections described from other parts of the VMH.

Thus, within the posterior division of the BST, the interfascicular and transverse nuclei contained a dense plexus of labeled fibers, whereas only a few axons appear to innervate the principal nucleus (Fig. 5D).
On the other hand, the anterior division of the BST receives a smaller number of labeled fibers, mainly distributed within the anterodorsal and anteroventral areas (Fig. 5B,C).

In addition, a few labeled axons could be traced to the lateral septa1 nucleus (Fig. 5A-C), to the nucleus accumbens (Fig. 5A), and to the infralimbic, prelimbic, and anterior cingulate areas (not illustrated).
Labeled fibers from the VMHa enter the amygdala following the same routes as described for the VMHvl (see above).

Compared to other parts of the VMH, the VMHa appears to provide a somewhat denser input to rostral areas of the amygdala (Fig. 5D), where anterograde labeling was mainly distributed within the medial and capsular parts of the central nucleus, the anterodorsal part of the medial nucleus, and the lateral nucleus (Fig. 5E-I).

It is worth noting that the piriform-amygdaloid area and caudal regions of the lateral zone of the posterior part of the cortical nucleus also appear to receive significant inputs from the VMHa (Fig. 5G-K).
In addition, labeled fibers from the VMHa could be traced to the endopiriform nucleus, the postpiriform transition area, and the piriform, perirhinal, and entorhinal areas (Fig. 5B-L).
Interestingly, the number of labeled fibers within rostral zones of the piriform area tends to be larger in experiments with injection sites involving the VMHa.
In addition, a few labeled mans were reliably found in the dorsal part and, in rostral zones of the posterior part, of the agranular insular area in these experiments (Fig. 5A-C).

As with other parts of the VMH, fibers arising in the VMHa project caudally through 1) the medial hypothalamus and medial forebrain bundle 2) the ventral supraoptic commissure system, and 3) the midbrain periventricular system.

At tuberal levels, descending fibers from the VMHa seem to provide only sparse inputs to other parts of the VMH as well as to adjacent regions of the ventral lateral hypothalamic area; in particular, they tend to avoid the dorsomedial nucleus and the periventricular region (Fig. 5G,H).

Caudal to the tuberal level, labeled fibers from the VMHa coursing through the medial zone and medial forebrain bundle generate a dense terminal field in the dorsal premammillary nucleus (Fig. 5J) and also appear to provide sparse inputs to the ventral premammillary, supramammillary, and medial mammillary nuclei (Fig. 51-K).

A few axons coursing through this pathway may continue farther caudally through the ventral tegmental area and appear to end in the rostral linear, central linear, and interfascicular nuclei of the raphe (Fig. 5K-0).

In addition, a small contingent of fibers descending through the medial zone of the hypothalamus and the medial forebrain bundle may also take a dorsolateral route to enter the zona incerta and then project to the same targets as described for other parts of the VMH (Fig. 5G-L).
The majority of descending fibers from the VMHa enter the posterior hypothalamic nucleus and extend caudally into the central gray.

A group of descending fibers from the VMHa courses through and appears to provide moderate inputs to the region of the zona incerta that contains the A13 dopaminergic cell group on their way to the posterior hypothalamic nucleus (Fig. 5G).

A group of fibers from the VMHa that descends through the posterior hypothalamic nucleus and rostral parts of the central gray may project to the thalamus and pretectal region in a way similar to that described for other parts of the VMH (Fig. 5H-M).
Interestingly, axons from the VMHa provide a distinct pattern of inputs to the central gray.

At rostral levels of the periaqueductal gray (Fig. 5K), as described for other parts of the VMH, anterogradely labeled fibers from the VMHa form a dense terminal field in a region adjacent to the subcommissural organ that includes the precommissural nucleus.

At the level of the Edinger-Westphal nucleus rostral to the oculomotor nucleus (Fig. 5L,M), labeled axons form a distinct terminal field in the peripheral half of the dorsolateral region (Fig. 5L), and, in proceeding caudally, a dense plexus of fibers was also observed within the peripheral half of the dorsal zone of the ventrolateral region of the periaqueductal gray (Fig. 5M).

Although the latter terminal field extends farther caudally, anterograde labeling diminishes sharply in the peripheral half of the dorsolateral region, which, as mentioned above, seems to correspond to a region of the periaqueductal gray delineated by very low levels of cytochrome oxidase staining (Conti et al., 1988; Fig. 5N,O).

At caudal levels of the periaqueductal gray, anterogradely labeled axons from the VMHa were distributed more widely in the ventrolateral region of the periaqueductal gray, similar to what was described for other parts of the VMH (Fig. 5P,Q).

A significant number of axons from the VMHa that course through the midbrain periventricular system project to the deep and intermediate layers of the superior colliculus, and, to a lesser extent, to caudal parts of the mesencephalic reticular nucleus (Fig. 5L-P).
Furthermore, axons coursing through this pathway may also provide sparse inputs to the cuneiform nucleus, parabrachial nucleus, and pontine central gray (Fig. 5P-R).

Only a small number of axons from the VMHa extend caudally through the ventral supraoptic commissure system, and they appear to provide sparse inputs to the ventral part of the lateral geniculate body, caudal pole of the reticular nucleus of the thalamus, and peripeduncular nucleus (Fig. 5H-M).
At this level, they merge with other descending fibers in the parvicellular part of the subparafascicular nucleus and zona incerta (Fig. 5L,M).

These fibers seem to extend caudally through the reticular core of the brainstem where, at pontine and medullary levels, occasional anterograde labeling was observed in the rostral and caudal parts of the pontine reticular nucleus (Fig. 5P-R), the gigantocellular reticular nucleus, and the nucleus of the solitary tract (not illustrated).

Results.S: Although the projections of the VMHa are mostly ipsilateral, a number of fibers cross the midline in the same pathways described for other parts of the VMH.
The contralateral projection resembles that on the ipsilateral side, but is much less dense.
Interestingly, the density of labeled fibers within the contralateral terminal fields was generally greater within the midbrain and pons as compared to the telencephalon.
Projections from the tuberal nucleus
Before describing the results of these experiments, our use of the term tuberal nucleus (TU) should be clarified because of some confusion in the recent literature.

Reexamination of the autoradiographs and adjacent Nissl-stained preparations used to describe the distribution of androgen and estrogen receptor mRNAs (Simerly et al., 1990,; see their Fig. 3E) showed a very restricted expression of the latter in a relatively homogeneous area of small to mediumsized neurons corresponding to the tuberal nucleus of Malone (19101, which has been identified in a wide range of mammals and is also known as the lateral tuberal nucleus (see Malone, 1914; Diepen, 1962, especially his Figs. 36,49, and Table 4; Nauta and Haymaker, 1969) because it lies along the base of the lateral tuberal eminence on either side of the median (tuberal) eminence.

Furthermore, several more or less distinct cell condensations have been described in most species (see Diepen, 19621, and lateral, intermediate, and subventromedial condensations may be observed in the rat (see Plate 29 in Swanson, 1992).
The approximate borders of the TU are indicated in Figure 6.

Unfortunately, Bleier et al. (1979) renamed this cell group the medial tuberal nucleus and called the rostral end of the traditional tuberomammillary nucleus (see Diepen, 1962) the lateral tuberal nucleus, designations adapted by Geeraedts et al. (1990), whose paraarcuate hypothalamic nucleus corresponds to the subventromedial region of the TU as defined here.

Paxinos and Watson (1986) also referred to the TU as the medial tuberal nucleus, although they separated out our lateral condensation of the TU as a separate, discrete hypothalamic nucleus (the terete hypothalamic nucleus) and referred to the rostral tuberomammillary nucleus (the lateral tuberal nucleus of Bleier et al., 1979; and Geeraedts et al., 1990) as the magnocellular nucleus of the lateral hypothalamus.

Interestingly, androgen receptor mRNA appears to be expressed preferentially in the subventromedial region of the TU (Simerly et al., 1990), the region of the TU that lies immediately adjacent to, and interrupts the capsule of, the VMH.

TTE.S: Four injections of PHA-L were centered in the TU, and, in two experiments, PHA-L-labeled neurons were almost entirely confined to this nucleus (experiments HLT 4 and HLT 5).

In both experiments, with PHA-L-labeled neurons virtually confined to the TU, we observed a very characteristic pattern of anterogradely labeled fibers resembling in may ways the pattern observed in experiments with PHA-L deposits restricted to the VMHv1.

To compare the pattern of outputs from the VMHvl with that from the adjacent TU, we shall use experiment HLT 5 as a prototype, which is illustrated schematically in Figure 6, and refer to the others where relevant.

At tuberal levels, labeled fibers from the injection site (Fig. 6J-L) seem to provide only a moderate input to the adjacent VMHvl, a lesser input to VMHc, and essentially little or no input to the VMHdm (Fig. 61-L).
In addition, a moderately dense plexus of fibers was observed in the dorsomedial nucleus and adjacent perifornical region at this level (Fig. 6J-L).
Within the dorsomedial nucleus, anterograde labeling was mainly distributed in the anterior and ventral parts and clearly tended to avoid the posterior part (Fig. 6J-L).

Compared to what was observed for the VMH, more labeled fibers from the TU enter the periventricular zone of the hypothalamus, where, at tuberal levels, they seem to provide moderate inputs to the arcuate and intermediate periventricular nuclei (Fig 6H-L).

Besides a projection to the arcuate nucleus, it is important to emphasize here that, in some experiments with an injection site centered in the TU, we also found an occasional labeled axon within the external lamina of the median eminence.
The bulk of ascending projections from the TU appear to travel through medial portions of the medial forebrain bundle and the medial zone of the hypothalamus.

At the anterior hypothalamic level, labeled axons from the TU form a moderately dense terminal field within rostral zones of the central part of the anterior hypothalamic nucleus, and this field extends dorsally to innervate the adjacent perifornical region.
The rest of the anterior hypothalamic nucleus, along with the subparaventricular zone (and perisuprachiasmatic region) contain a much sparser plexus of labeled fibers (Fig. 6F-I).

Furthermore, at this level, a number of labeled fibers could also be traced to the periventricular region, where they appear to provide inputs to the anterior and intermediate periventricular nuclei as well as to the parvicellular division of the paraventricular nucleus (Fig. 6E-I).

Proceeding rostrally, many fibers reach the preoptic region and appear to provide massive inputs to undifferentiated parts of the medial preoptic area, the lateral part of the medial preoptic nucleus, and the anteroventral preoptic nucleus, in a pattern similar to that described for the VMHvl (Fig. 6C-F).
A group of fibers ascending from the injection site through the hypothalamus also seems to project to rostral parts of the zona incerta and to the thalamus.
Within the latter, labeled fibers provide moderate inputs to rostral parts of the paraventricular nucleus and nucleus reuniens in particular (Fig. 6F-I).
Like the VMH, the TU also provides rather massive inputs to the septal region.
Ascending fibers from the TU reach the septal region via the same pathways described for the VMHvl (see above).
The overall distribution pattern of labeled fibers within the BST was also very similar to that described for the VMHvl (Fig. 6C-F).
However, the lateral septal nucleus apparently receives a somewhat denser projection from the TU, with labeled fibers distributed mainly within the intermediate part of the nucleus (Fig. 6A-E).
In addition to the lateral septal nucleus, a few axons could also be found reliably in the septofimbrial and medial septal nuclei (Fig. 6B-E).

A small number of fibers continue rostral to the septal region and appear to provide sparse inputs to the nucleus accumbens (Fig. 6A,B) as well as to the infralimbic and prelimbic areas (not illustrated).
In contrast to what was demonstrated for the VMHv1, many fewer axons from the TU could be traced to the amygdala.
The bulk of labeled fibers to the amygdala course through the ansa peduncularis, although a small number were also observed coursing through the stria terminalis.
The majority of fibers in the ansa peduncularis lie within the substantia innominata, although some travel directly through the lateral hypothalamic area, before entering the amygdala (Fig. 6E-I).
It is important to emphasize that fibers coursing through the substantia innominata display a significant number of boutons-of-passage.
Interestingly, only a few axons from the injection site enter the supraoptic commissure system to enter the amygdala (Fig. 6J,K).

Axons projecting to the amygdala from the TU appear to ramify mainly in the medial and capsular parts of the central nucleus as well as in the anterodorsal and posterodorsal parts of the medial nucleus, although there are very sparse inputs to several other nuclei (Fig. 6E-0).
Occasional labeled fibers passing through the amygdala could also be followed to the piriform, perirhinal, entorhinal, and postpiriform transition areas (Fig. 6K-0).
Descending axons from the TU follow basically the same routes as described for the VMHvl.
A large group of fibers extends caudally from the injection site through medial parts of the medial forebrain bundle and the medial zone of the hypothalamus.

Just caudal to the injection site, these fibers generate a very dense terminal field in lateral parts of the ventral premammillary nucleus and also appear to provide moderately dense inputs to ventral parts of the posterior hypothalamic nucleus; clearly, they tend to avoid the dorsal premammillary nucleus (Fig. 6M,N).

A number of fibers in this pathway at mammillary levels innervate the supramammillary nucleus, and then extend farther caudally through the ventral tegmental area, providing inputs to the rostral linear, central linear, and interfascicular nuclei of the raphe (Fig. 60-Q).
It is important to point out here that, compared to the VMHv1, the TU appears to project more densely to all of the regions just described as receiving fibers in this pathway.
A small contingent of fibers descending through the medial forebrain bundle and medial zone of the hypothalamus may also extend dorsolaterally to enter the zona incerta, where they extend caudally.
At the level of the peripeduncular nucleus, they join other groups of fibers descending through the subparafascicular nucleus and the ventral supraoptic commissure system (Fig. 6K-P).
In sharp contrast to the VMHv1, a much smaller number of fibers extend caudally through the posterior hypothalamic nucleus into the midbrain periventricular system.

Some fibers in this pathway enter the thalamus where, in addition to sparse projections to caudal parts of the paraventricular and intermediodorsal nuclei, they appear to provide a significant input to medial zones of the lateral habenula (Fig. 6K-N).

Fibers in the midbrain periventricular system extend caudally though the periaqueductal gray and at caudal levels form a distinct terminal field in the ventrolatera1 region immediately dorsal to the laterodorsal tegmental nucleus (Fig. 60-R).
Proceeding caudally, a number of fibers continue into the pontine central gray, where a moderate terminal field was found in Barrington s nucleus (Fig. 6s).
In addition, some fibers in this pathway may also project to the deep layers of the superior colliculus and the mesencephalic reticular, cuneiform, and parabrachial nuclei (Fig. 6P-s).

In contrast to what was described for the VMHvl, only a small number of fibers from the TU extend caudally through the ventral supraoptic commissure system; they appear to provide sparse inputs to the ventral part of the lateral geniculate body, the caudal pole of the reticular nucleus of the thalamus, and the peripeduncular nucleus (Fig. 6L-P).

At the level of the peripeduncular nucleus, these fibers join other groups of fibers descending through the zona incerta (as described above) and the subparafascicular nucleus, and together they appear to provide inputs to the mesencephalic reticular nucleus.

A few of these axons may continue farther caudally into pontine and medullary levels of the brainstem, where occasional anterograde labeling was found in the rostral and caudal parts of the pontine reticular nucleus, gigantocellular reticular nucleus, nucleus raphe magnus, and nucleus of the solitary tract.

Results.S: The projections of the TU are mostly ipsilateral, although a number of fibers cross the midline to provide a similar, though much less dense, pattern of inputs to the contralatera1 side of the brain.
Pathways followed by these crossing fibers are virtually the same as those described for the VMHv1.

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION
Projections of the ventromedial nucleus

Our results confirm and extend in many ways the conclusions drawn by previous workers using the autoradiographic method to delineate projections of the VMH (Conrad and PfaE, 1976; Saper et al., 1976; Krieger et al., 1979).

The PHA-L method (Gerfen and Sawchenko, 1984) has the following clear advantages over the autoradiographic method: 1) It is a more sensitive anterograde tract-tracing method; 2) small injection sites may be produced and delineated accurately; and 3) individual labeled axons may be visualized with the clarity of a Golgi impregnation, so that a differentiation between preterminal pathways and primary terminal fields can sometimes be established with relative certainty.

Terminal bouton and bouton-of-passage are light microscopic terms long used to describe axonal morphology (e.g., Cajal 1909-1911), and, whenever these structures have been examined with the electron microscope, they have been found to establish synapses (see Canteras et al., 1992a).

Therefore, in the present study, using the PHA-L method, we were able to obtain a relatively accurate profile of the pattern of efferent projections from each part of the VMH, although we could not determine whether varicose fibers with no boutons establish terminal fields.

One of the main conclusions to be drawn from our work is that the anterior, dorsomedial, central, and ventrolateral parts of the VMH present significant differences with regard to their projection patterns.

However, it may be important to point out that, whereas cytological work indicates that the dorsomedid and ventrolateral parts of the VMH may be further subdivided into anterior and posterior sectors (Van Houten and Brawer, 19781, no clear differences were observed in the distribution of anterogradely labeled fibers between experiments with PHA-L injections placed at different rostrocaudal levels within each of these two parts of the VMH.

Our findings also corroborate previous studies indicating massive intrinsic connections within the VMH (Millhouse, 1973; Nishizuca and Pfaff, 1989) and expand these observations to indicate that to be segregated within the intra-VMH projections tend each part of the nucleus.

In all experiments with PHA-L deposits centered in the VMH, regardless of differences observed in the distribution pattern of terminal fields, labeled axons followed the same basic routes (for summary, see Fig. 9).

Furthermore, the output of the VMH appears to be largely ipsilateral, although it is important to point out that a significant contingent of fibers crosses the midline, particularly through the ventral supraoptic commissure and through the region dorsal to the cerebral aqueduct.

Axons projecting from the VMH may be divided into an ascending group that innervates targets rostral to the nucleus in the diencephalon and telencephalon and a descending group to the caudal hypothalamus and brainstem.

Ascending fibers from the nucleus course mainly through the medial zone of the hypothalamus and medial portions of the medial forebrain bundle, whereas a smaller group of axons extends rostrally through rostral parts of the zona incerta just dorsal to the hypothalamus.

Some of the fibers ascending through these pathways take a dorsal route and enter the thalamus, and, at preoptic levels, a significant number of fibers extend through the septa1 region and may continue as far rostral as the infralimbic and prelimbic areas of the medial prefrontal cortex.

In addition, a group of ascending fibers takes a lateral course, mainly following the ansa peduncularis through the substantia innominata and the ventral supraoptic commissure system, thus gaining access to the amygdala and temporal cortical areas.

Descending fibers from the VMH follow three main routes: 1) the medial hypothalamus and medial forebrain bundle; 2) the midbrain periventricular system (Cajal s periependymal longitudinal fascicle); and 3) the ventral supraoptic commissure system.

In addition, at the level of the mesencephalic reticular nucleus, some fibers descending through these pathways merge and appear to extend caudally into pontine and medullary levels of the reticular core of the brainstem.
Intrahypothalamic projections.
The VMH establishes extensive intrahypothalamic connections, particularly with medial zone structures.
Our findings indicate that different parts of the VMH provide distinct intrahypothalamic projection patterns.

Thus, as a general rule, we may say that the pattern of intrahypothalamic projections from the VMHdm and VMHc are somewhat similar, differing markedly, however, from that observed for the VMHa and VMHv1.

At anterior hypothalamic levels, ascending fibers from the VMH provide a dense innervation to the anterior hypothalamic nucleus, retrochiasmatic area, perifornical region, and subparaventricular zone, including regions around the suprachiasmatic nucleus.

Inputs to the anterior hypothalamic nucleus were inferred from previous autoradiographic studies (Conrad and Pfaff, 1976; Saper et al., 1976; Krieger et al., 1979), although these observations were limited by methodological constraints that make accurate evaluation of short axonal pathways difficult in autoradiographic material.

According to our results, the VMHdm and VMHc provide more inputs to the anterior hypothalamic nucleus, where particularly dense terminal fields were observed in the anterior and posterior parts of the nucleus.

In contrast, fibers arising in the VMHvl and VMHa do not seem to provide a significant input to these parts of the anterior hypothalamic nucleus, providing instead a dense input to rostra1 zones of the central part of the nucleus.

In agreement with our findings, Cullinan and Zaborsky (1991) have also described a dense terminal field within the anterior part of the anterior hypothalamic nucleus after PHA-L-deposits centered in the VMHdm and VMHc.

To understand the possible implications of this topographic arrangement of projections from the VMH to the anterior hypothalamic nucleus, it is important to know that each part of the anterior hypothalamic nucleus gives rise to a distinct pattern of projections (see Risold et al., 1994).
Notably, the anterior hypothalamic nucleus in turn provides dense inputs to the VMHc and especially the VMHdm (Risold et al., 1994).
Therefore, these observations taken together suggest the existence of a prominent, topographically organized intrahypothalamic loop between the VMH and the anterior hypothalamic nucleus.

In agreement with previous studies using the autoradiographic anterograde tracing method (Saper et al., 1976) or retrograde tract-tracing techniques (Simerly and Swanson, 1986), we also confirmed that the majority of fibers from the VMH innervating the preoptic region arise from the VMHv1.
According to our observations, the VMHvl provides dense inputs to undifferentiated parts of the medial preoptic area and the lateral part of the medial preoptic nucleus.
At tuberal levels, we observed that the TU appears to receive a significant input from the VMHv1, whereas other parts of the VMH provide only a small number of fibers to this region.

It is important to point out that, like the VMHvl, the adjoining TU is also an estrogen-concentrating region, and, in addition to providing direct inputs to the VMHvl, the TU presents a pattern of efferent projections resembling in vmy ways those described for the VMHv1.
The dorsomedial nucleus of the hypothalamus also appears to receive a moderate innervation, particularly from the VMHc and to a lesser extent from the VMHvl as well.

Luiten et al. (19871, using the PHA-L method, also described a projection from the VMH to the dorsomedial nucleus and, in contrast to our results, viewed the dorsomedial nucleus as one of the main targets of the VMH.
The reason for this discrepancy is not apparent.

In view of the fact that the dorsomedial nucleus provides dense inputs to parvicellular parts of the paraventricular nucleus and, to a lesser extent, to the arcuate nucleus (Ter Horst and Luiten, 1986; Thompson et al., 19921, it may represent an important gateway to neurosecretory motoneurons.
Just caudal to the VMH, descending fibers from the VMHvl provide a sparse input to the ventral premammillary nucleus and tend to avoid the dorsal premammillary nucleus.

On the other hand, whereas the VMHc projects sparsely to both the dorsal and ventral premammillary nuclei, fibers from the VMHdm and VMHa provide a moderate to dense innervation, especially to the dorsal premammillary nucleus.
Our results are in agreement with those of Saper et al. (1976) who inferred that the VMHdm, but not the VMHv1, projects to the dorsal premammillary nucleus.

It is worth noting that the ventral premammillary nucleus, in addition to providing dense inputs to the periventricular zone of the hypothalamus, also projects massively to the sexually dimorphic circuit (Canteras et al., 1992b).

In contrast, the dorsal premammillary nucleus gives rise to a branched pathway ending in the anterior thalamic group and periaqueductal gray in addition to a significant input to the anterior hypothalamic nucleus (Canteras and Swanson, 1992a).

In agreement with previous autoradiographic studies (Saper et al., 1976; Krieger at al., 19791, we also observed that all parts of the VMH project sparsely to the supramammillary nucleus and the capsule surrounding the medial mammillary nucleus.

Finally, it is important to note that all parts of the VMH give rise to a number of fibers that, on their way to the midbrain periventricular pathway, extend through the posterior hypothalamic nucleus, where they almost certainly establish a large number of synapses.
In contrast to dense inputs to the medial zone of the hypothalamus, the VMH generates only a sparse projection to the periventricular zone.

Although previous autoradiographic studies tended to conclude that the VMH extends a significant projection to the periventricular zone of the hypothalamus, particularly to the arcuate nucleus, we should consider first that the relevant injection sites usually also included the ventral premammillary nucleus, which projects densely to the arcuate nucleus as well as other regions the periventricular zone (Canteras et al., 1992b); and second, considering the proximity of the VMH, especially to the arcuate nucleus, the autoradiographic method is less than ideal for analyzing possible connections between these adjacent structures.

In agreement with previous anterograde autoradiographic (Saper et al., 1976) and retrograde tracer (Wiegand and Price, 1980) studies, our observations clearly indicate that the median eminence does not receive a direct projection from the VMH.

Interestingly, however, occasional labeled fibers from the VMH were observed crossing to the other side of the brain sandwiched between the internal lamina of the median eminence and the ependymal wall of the third ventricle.

In summary, our results on the intrahypothalamic connections of the VMH clearly suggest that the VMHvl is more closely related to other hypothalamic structures that also contain high densities of gonadal steroid-concentrating neurons (Pfaff and Keiner, 1973; Sar and Stumpf, 1975; Stumpf et al., 1975) and express mRNAs encoding the androgen and/or estrogen receptors (Simerly et al., 19901, including the medial preoptic nucleus, TU, and ventral premammillary nucleus.
In contrast, other parts of the VMH establish particularly dense connections with the anterior hypothalamic nucleus and also to a lesser extent with the dorsal premammillary nucleus.

This dichotomy strengthens the idea of two partially segregated intrahypothalamic circuits within the medial zone of the hypothalamus, with one including primarily the medial preoptic nucleus, VMHv1, TU, and ventral premammillary nucleus; and the other including the anterior hypothalamic nucleus, VMHa, c and dm, and dorsal premammillary nucleus.
Projections to the ventral and dorsal thalamus.
The ventral thalamus also receives significant inputs from all parts of the VMH, with moderate inputs to the region of the A13 dopaminergic cell group and rostral pole of the zona incerta.
