Electrophysiological work has suggested that an output from the VMH to medial portions of the zona incerta, including the region of the A13 dopaminergic cell group, is predominantly excitatory (Eaton and Moss, 1989).

These findings are of interest because the A13 dopaminergic cell group, like the VMH, has been implicated in the expression of reproductive behavior as well as in the control of prolactin and gonadotropin release (Sanghera et al., 1991; Wilson et al., 1991).

Furthermore, as previously described in anterograde autoradiographic (Conrad and Pfaff, 1976; Saper et al., 1976; Kreiger et al., 1979) and retrograde transport (Shammah-Lagnado et al., 1985) studies, the VMH also provides a sparser input to more caudal regions of the zona incerta.

In agreement with previous autoradiographic data, our material also indicates that the VMH sends axons diffusely into the dorsal thalamus, where especially dense projections were observed to the paraventricular and parataenial nuclei, as well as to the nucleus reuniens.

Evidence for a projection from the VMH to the paraventricular and parataenial nuclei as well as to the nucleus reuniens was also reported in earlier retrograde tracer studies (Herkenham, 1978; Cornwall and Phillipson, 1988; Chen and Su, 1990).
Interestingly, our results clearly indicate that fibers from the VMHa provide especially dense inputs to the ventral part of the rostral pole of the nucleus reuniens.
The possible functional significance of projections from the VMH to these midline thalamic nuclei will be discussed below (see under Functional implications).
Projections to the telencephalon.
Ascending fibers from the VMH enter the septal region, where the BST in particular appears to receive a rather dense input.

The projection from the VMH to the septum has also been described in previous anterograde (Conrad and Pfaff, 1976; Saper et al., 1976; Krieger et al., 1979) and retrograde tracer studies (Luiten at al., 1982; Weller and Smith, 1982).
In agreement with previous findings of Saper et al. (19761, our observations indicate that the VMHvl as well as the VMHc provide denser inputs to the septum than other parts of the VMH.

Thus, the VMHv1 and VMHc send a dense projection to the transverse and interfascicular nuclei of the posterior division of the BST as well as to the anteroventral and anterodorsal areas of the BST in addition to a lighter projection to the lateral septal nucleus.

The VMHdm and VMHa also provide a substantial input to the transverse and interfascicular nuclei of the BST, although, in contrast to other parts of the VMH, they project more sparsely to other parts of the BST and other septal nuclei.

In addition to the septum, a small number of axons from all parts of the VMH could also be traced farther rostrally to the nucleus accumbens and to the infralimbic, prelimbic, and anterior cingulate areas.
A majority of the fibers from the VMH that project to the amygdala travel through the ansa peduncularis, whereas only a few course through the stria terminalis.
Two distinct bundles of fibers coursing toward the amygdala were observed within the ansa peduncularis.

At caudal levels, axons were followed through the ipsilateral ventral supraoptic commissure system, and at rostral levels a contingent of ascending fibers turns ventrolaterally, coursing through the substantia innominata.

While coursing through the latter, these axom display a number of boutons-of-passage, although, as suggested by Cullinan and Zaborsky (19911, they apparently do not contact a significant number of cholinergic neurons in this region.

Previous anterograde (Conrad and Pfaff, 1976; Saper et al., 1976; Krieger at al., 1979) and retrograde (Renaud and Hopkins, 1977; Veening, 1978; Ottersen, 1980; Luiten et al., 1985) tract-tracing studies indicated that the VMH provides inputs to several regions within the amygdala, and the VMH is usually considered to be one of the principal sources of hypothalamic inputs to the amygdala.

According to our results, the VMH provides substantial inputs to several parts of the amygdala, including the capsular and medial parts of the central nucleus, the lateral nucleus, the anterodorsal part of the medial nucleus, and the piriformamygdaloid area.
In addition, it was observed that each part of the VMH provides a somewhat different pattern of projections to the amygdala (see Results).

The central and lateral nuclei appear to receive the most abundant inputs from the VMH, and, notably, the influence of the VMH on the lateral nucleus may be further strengthened via the piriform-amygdaloid area, which is known to provide dense inputs to the lateral nucleus (Canteras et al., 1992a).

It may also be worth noting that the projection from the VMH to the medial nucleus of the amygdala is not nearly as dense as the projection received by the VMH from the medial nucleus (Krettek and Price, 1978); it is tempting to suggest that this feedback pathway may serve to monitor the output of the VMH.

Our observations also indicate that a small group of fibers from the VMH coursing through the ansa peduncularis ends in limited regions adjacent to the amygdala, including the piriform area and endopiriform nucleus as well as the perirhinal, entorhinal, and postpiriform transition areas.
In addition, particularly in experiments with injection sites involving the VMHa, labeled fibers could be traced to the agranular insular area.
Projections to the brainstem.
Our observations indicate that different parts of the VMH provide somewhat different patterns of input to the brainstem.

Fibers from the VMH continue to the brainstem chiefly through the midbrain periventricular system, although a considerable number of axons arising in the VMHvl extend caudally through the ventral supraoptic commissure.

Only a few descending fibers from the VMH running through the medial zone of the hypothalamus and medial forebrain bundle appear to extend caudal to the hypothalamus, and they seem to end in the ventral tegmental area as well as in the rostra1 linear, central linear, and interfascicular nuclei of the raph6.

In addition, a group of fibers descending through the medial hypothalamus and medial forebrain bundle may also follow a dorsolateral route and enter the zona incerta, where they extend caudally and merge with other descending fibers in the region of the peripeduncular nucleus.
Descending axons from the VMH that extend through the midbrain periventricular system course initially through the posterior hypothalamic nucleus.

In agreement with previous anterograde data (Conrad and Pfaff, 1976; Krieger et al., 19791, we have also observed in our material that some of the fibers passing through the posterior hypothalamic area take a lateral course ventral to the parafascicular nucleus and then extend caudally through the subparafascicular nucleus just dorsal to the medial lemniscus.

Although boutons-of-passage are found all along the labeled fibers within both the magnocellular and parvicellular parts of this nucleus, fibers coursing through this pathway appear to innervate mainly caudal regions of the parvicellular part of the subparafascicular nucleus, where it merges with the peripeduncular nucleus, which also appears to receive fibers in this pathway.

Inputs from the VMH to the peripeduncular nucleus, as well as caudal parts of the subparafascicular nucleus, may also arrive by way of the ventral supraoptic commissure and caudal portions of the zona incerta.

The region encompassing caudal parts of the subparafascicular nucleus ventral to the medial geniculate body as well as the peripeduncular nucleus, as delineated in the schematic representations of the present study, has been referred to generically by several authors as the peripedundular area (see Arnault and Roger, 1987).

The projection from the VMH to the so-called peripeduncular area has also been reported in previous anterograde and retrograde studies (Saper et al., 1976; Krieger et al., 1979; Le Doux et al., 1985; Arnault and Roger, 1987).

Notably, axons from the VMH that project to the peripeduncular area, extending caudally either through the subparafascicular nucleus or through the ventral supraoptic commissure, arise chiefly from the VMHvl.

The peripeduncular area is known to project back to the VMH, possibly conveying information from the spinal cord and several auditory-related structures (Le Doux et al., 1985, 1987; Arnault and Roger, 1987).

Interestingly, the peripeduncular area, in addition to providing inputs to distinct auditory relay nuclei and the auditory cortex (Le Doux et al., 1985; Arnault and Roger, 19871, also projects to a number of structures that also receive inputs from the VMH, including the medial, central, and lateral nuclei of the amygdala (Ottersen, 1981; Arnault and Roger, 1987) and the periaqueductal gray (Le Doux et al., 1985; Arnault and Roger, 1987).
Like the VMH, it may also play an important role in the lordosis reflex (Carrer, 1978; Lopez and Carrer, 1985).
The vast majority of fibers from the VMH that course through the midbrain periventricular system appear to innervate the periaqueductal gray.

This projection has been well characterized in a number of studies using anterograde or retrograde tract-tracing methods (Conrad and Pfaff, 1976; Saper et al., 1976; Krieger et al., 1979; Morrell et al., 1981; Beitz, 1982; Marchand and Hagino, 1983; Meller and Dennis, 1986; Luiten et al., 1987), electrophysiological methods (Sakuma and Tada, 19841, and electron microscopy (Chung et al., 1990) as well as methods combining steroid hormone autoradiography or immunohistochemistry with retrograde tracing (Morrell and Pfaff, 1982; Yamano et al., 1986; DonCarlos and Morrell, 1990; Dornan et al., 1990; Lisciotto and Morrell, 1990).
In the present experiments, we observed that the projection from the VMH to the periaqueductal gray is very dense and more highly organized than previously suspected.

As a general rule, all parts of the VMH project along the entire rostrocaudal axis of the periaqueductal gray in longitudinally organized regions, with different parts of the VMH providing distinct patterns of innervation (see Results).

For example, at the level of the oculomotor nucleus, whereas the VMHdm provides significant inputs to dorsal and dorsolateral regions of the periaqueductal gray, axons from the VMHa apparently tend to avoid these regions and form a distinct terminal field in the lateral half of dorsal zone of the ventrolateral region, whereas axons from the VMHvl course through the dorsal and ventrolateral regions of the periaqueductal gray, where they apparently provide only a few boutons and varicosities.
At caudal levels, on the other hand, the ventrolateral region of the periaqueductal gray appears to receive a denser and more widespread innervation from the VMHv1.
As we shall discuss below, our findings reinforce the idea that the periaqueductal gray may serve as an important interface for the VMH in the mediation of several behavioral and autonomic responses.
In addition, a group of fibers coursing through the midbrain periventricular system also appears to innervate deeper layers of the superior colliculus as well as the mesencephalic reticular nucleus.

The projection from the VMH to the deeper layers of the superior colliculus was suggested by earlier retrograde data (Cadusseau and Roger, 19851, whereas inputs to the mesencephalic reticular nucleus were inferred in previous autoradiographic studies (Conrad and Pfaff, 1976; Krieger et al., 1979).

Apart from axons coursing through the periventricular system, it is important to point out that the mesencephalic reticular nucleus may also receive fibers that reach the brainstem by traveling through the subparafascicular nucleus, ventral supraoptic commissure system, and caudal zona incerta.
At the caudal pole of the periaqueductal gray, a number of fibers arising in the VMH enter the cuneiform nucleus, where they seem to provide a moderate terminal field.
Furthermore, as previously reported by Moga et al. (1990), a few axons may also extend to the parabrachial nucleus, providing very sparse inputs chiefly to the lateral division of the nucleus.

In agreement with previous autoradiographic studies (Conrad and Pfaff, 1976; Saper et al., 1976; Krieger et al., 1979), only a few axons traveling through the midbrain periventricular system extend caudally into the pontine central gray, where, according to our observations, they provide an input chiefly to Barrington s nucleus with only occasional fibers observed within the borders of the locus coeruleus.
Finally, a very small number of fibers in the mesencephalic reticular nucleus may extend caudal to the midbrain in the reticular core of the brainstem, reaching as far as the caudal medulla.

In our experiments with PHA-L deposits centered in theVMH, labeled fibers could be found occasionally in the pontine, gigantocellular, paragigantocellular, and parvicellular reticular nuclei as well as in the nucleus of the solitary tract.

Our observations corroborate the results of Swanson and Kuypers (1980), who demonstrated a few retrogradely labeled cells within the VMH after injections of fluorescent retrograde tracer in the dorsal medulla, although these authors also demonstrated a very limited projection from the VMH to the spinal cord that was not detected in our experiments.

Morphological differences in the VMH of male and female rats have been shown (Matsumoto and Arai, 1983, 1986) along with sex differences in estrogen, progestin, and oxytocin binding (Brown et al., 1987, 1992; Lauber et al., 1991; Coirini et al., 1992) and the number of cholecystokinin-immunoreactive elements (see Akesson and Micevych, 1988).
In the present study, we have not specifically examined the projections of the VMH in female animals.

However, the results of previous anatomical studies of other sexually dimorphic areas, such as the medial preoptic nucleus, suggest a qualitatively similar pattern of projections in both sexes, whereas quantitative differences within particular terminal fields may be expected (see Simerly and Swanson, 1988).
Projections of the tuberal nucleus
We have also examined the projections of the discrete estrogen-concentrating TU adjacent to the VMHv1.

It is worth pointing out that, in contrast to the VMHvl, neurons within the TU do not appear to express progesterone receptors (Romano et al., 1989a) and normally express very little preproenkephalin (Harlan et al., 1987) and preprotachykinin (Romano et al., 198913) mRNAs.

In addition, recent studies have shown that oxytocin binding sites normally observed in the TU are reduced about 80% after lesions of the VMHvl, suggesting that oxytocin receptors are located on fibers arising in the VMHv1, not on cells within the adjacent TU itself (Johnson et al., 1991).
Therefore, apart from the presence of estrogen receptors, cells within the TU are biochemically distinct from those within the VMHvl.
The present results suggest that the output of the TU may be viewed as a subset of that described for the VMHvl (for summary see Fig. 9).
Labeled fibers arising in the TU followed the same basic routes as those described for the VMHvI, although rather subtile differences in their projection patterns were observed.
Like the VMHvl, the TU establishes broad intrahypothalamic connections, particularly with structures in the medial zone.

At tuberal levels, the TU provides a moderate input to the VMHvl and a sparse input to the VMHc, whereas the dorsomedial nucleus and adjacent perifornical region appear to receive a fairly substantial input.
The TU supplies a denser input than the VMHvl to the dorsomedial nucleus, which, as noted above, may represent an important gateway to neurosecretory motoneurons.
At the anterior hypothalamic level, the TU provides an especially dense input to rostral zones of the central part of the anterior hypothalamic nucleus and adjacent perifornical region.
However, this projection to the anterior hypothalamic nucleus, in addition to showing a different topographic distribution, is not nearly as dense as that described for the VMHv1.
Furthermore, the TU provides a much sparser input to the subparaventricular zone and perisuprachiasmatic region than the adjacent VMHv1.

In agreement with previous retrograde studies (Simerly and Swanson, 1986), we also observed that the TU provides a substantial projection to the preoptic level, where, like the VMHv1, it ends massively in undifferentiated parts of the medial preoptic area and in the lateral part of the medial preoptic nucleus.
In this context, it is worth noting that the medial preoptic nucleus in turn also provides a dense input to the TU (Simerly and Swanson, 1988).
Just caudal to the VMH, the TU provides a massive input to lateral zones of the ventral premammillary nucleus, which, in contrast, appears to receive only a sparse-tomoderate input from the VMHv1.

Like the medial preoptic nucleus, the ventral premammillary nucleus issues a strong projection to the TU and, as noted above, may also represent another gateway for the TU to influence neurosecretory motoneurones (Canteras et al., 1992b).

As with the VMHvl, fibers arising in the TU tend to avoid the dorsal premammillary nucleus, although they generate a substantial terminal field in ventral zones of the posterior hypothalamic nucleus adjacent to the dorsal premammillary nucleus, a region that our observations suggest does not receive substantial inputs from the VMH.

Compared to what was described for the VMHv1, at mammillary levels, the TU provides a somewhat denser input to the supramammillary nucleus in addition to a sparse input to the capsule surrounding the medial mammillary nucleus.

In summary, when comparing the hodological relationships of the TU with other medial zone nuclei of the hypothalamus, it becomes obvious that, like the adjacent VMHv1, the TU also provides dense inputs to other hypothalamic cell groups that contain high densities of gonadal steroid-concentrating neurons (Pfaff and Keiner, 1973; Sar and Stumpf, 1975; Stumpf et al., 1975) and express mRNAs encoding the androgen and/or estrogen receptors (Simerly et al., 1990), including the medial preoptic nucleus, VMHv1, and ventral premammillary nucleus.

Aside from providing denser inputs than the VMHvl to the ventral premammillary and dorsomedial nuclei, both of which are thought to be important gateways to neurosecretory motoneurons (see above), the TU also provides somewhat denser projections to several regions of the hypothalamic periventricular zone, including the arcuate, anterior periventricular, and intermediate periventricular nuclei as well as parvicellular parts of the paraventricular nucleus, all of which are known to contain neurosecretory motoneurons (see Swanson, 1987).
The present findings suggest, therefore, that the TU may have a stronger direct influence than the VMHvl on neuroendocrine control mechanisms.
In this context, it is worth recalling that a few neurons within the TU express growth hormone-releasing hormone (GRH), but apparently do not project to the median eminence.
They may thus contribute to extrahypophysiotropic projections, especially in the periventricular zone (Sawchenko et al., 1985).
Although our results support this view, some experiments with an injection site centered in the TU labeled an occasional axon within the external lamina of the median eminence.
The TU provides a sparse input to the ventral thalamus.
Thus, the region of the A13 dopaminergic cell group and rostral pole of the zona incerta appears to receive only a sparse input, which contrasts with a denser input from the VMHvl.
However, like the VMHvl, the TU provides a moderate input to several midline thalamic nuclei, including the nucleus reuniens and the paraventricular nucleus.
On the other hand, the TU supplies a somewhat denser projection to the lateral habenula than the VMHvl.

Evidence for a projection from the TU, as well as many parts of the lateral zone of the hypothalamus, to the lateral habenula was reported in earlier retrograde tracer studies (Herkenham and Nauta, 1977).
Our observations indicate that the TU projects densely to the septal region in a pattern similar to that described for the VMHv1.
The projection to the BST is virtually identical to that from the VMHvl, although the TU provides a somewhat denser projection to the intermediate lateral septal nucleus.
A projection from the TU to the lateral septal nucleus was indicated in a previous retrograde tracer study (Luiten et al., 1982).
As with the VMH, some fibers arising in the TU also continue rostral to the septal region, providing sparse inputs to the nucleus accumbens as well as the infralimbic and prelimbic areas.
In sharp contrast to what was described for various parts of the VMH, the TU appears to provide a much sparser input to the amygdala.
As with the VMH, a majority of the fibers from the TU reach the amygdala by traveling through the ansa peduncularis.

However, within the ansa peduncularis, fibers arising in the TU course preferentially through the substantia innominata, whereas, in contrast to what was described for the VMH, only a few axons appear to follow the ventral supraoptic commissure.

Within the amygdala, these fibers appear to provide significant inputs to the medial and capsular parts of the central nucleus as well as to the anterodorsal and posterodorsal parts of the medial nucleus.
In contrast, the lateral nucleus, which is densely innervated by the VMH, appears to receive only a very sparse projection from the adjacent TU.
In line with our findings, a previous retrograde tract tracing study suggested a projection from the TU to the central and medial nuclei of the amygdala (Ottersen, 1980).
As a whole, the brainstem receives less dense inputs from the TU than from the VMH.

Furthermore, the pattern of projections from the TU to the brainstem is much more similar to those described for the VMH than it is to the pattern described for projections from adjacent parts of the tuberal lateral hypothalamic area (see Saper et al., 1979; Allen and Cechetto, 1992).
As with the VMH, fibers arising in the TU reach the brainstem by following the medial forebrain bundle, the midbrain periventricular system, and the ventral supraoptic commissure system.

In contrast to the adjacent VMHv1, only a very small number of fibers arising in the TU extend caudally through the ventral supraoptic commissure, whereas a larger number of fibers coursing through the medial forebrain bundle extend caudal to the hypothalamus and appear to provide a somewhat denser input to the central linear nucleus of the raphe in particular as well as to the ventral tegmental area.
A smaller number of axons from the TU than from the VMH extend caudally through the posterior hypothalamic nucleus into the midbrain periventricular system.

These fibers appear to provide significant inputs to the periaqueductal gray and pontine central gray, along with sparse projections to deeper layers of the superior colliculus, mesencephalic reticular nucleus, cuneiform nucleus, and parabrachial nucleus.

The projection from the TU to the periaqueductal gray has also been suggested by previous retrograde studies (Morrell et al., 1981; Beitz, 1982; Meller and Dennis, 1986), and we showed more directly here that, like the VMHv1, the TU provides a denser input to caudal levels of the ventrolateral part of the periaqueductal gray.
Within the pontine central gray, the TU generates a distinct terminal field in a region just rostral to the locus coeruleus that is thought to constitute Barrington s nucleus.
The mesencephalic reticular nucleus may also receive fibers that travel from the TU as well as from the VMH through the ventral supraoptic commissure system and caudal zona incerta.

Although a majority of these fibers appear to end within this nucleus, a very few extend caudally into pontine and medullary levels, where they apparently end in the rostral and caudal parts of the pontine reticular nucleus, the gigantocellular reticular nucleus, the nucleus raphe magnus, and the nucleus of the solitary tract.
Swanson and Kuypers (1980), using fluorescent retrograde tracers, also indicated that the TU may provide a very sparse projection the medulla.
In addition, they suggested the existence of a sparse projection to the spinal cord, which could not be detected in our material.
Functional implications

Like other medial zone nuclei of the hypothalamus, the VMH serves to integrate forebrain neural influences with ascending information from the brainstem, and distribute the resulting output to regions involved in the control of visceral and behavioral mechanisms (see Swanson, 1987).

The VMH has been implicated in mechanisms regulating the release of various pituitary hormones including growth hormone (Kato et al., 1983, 1985; Okada et al., 19911, prolactin (Pan and Gala, 19851, and luteinizing hormone (Chateau at al., 1984; Blanche et al., 1991).
In addition, the nucleus has been said to play a role in controlling the duration of the estrous cycle (Chateau et al., 1981, 1984).

Our results suggest that the VMH sends only very sparse projections directly to parvicellular neurosecretory regions of the periventricular zone of the hypothalamus known to control the release of growth hormone and prolactin (see Swanson, 1987) and does not seem to innervate to any significant extent regions that contain neurons expressing gonadotropin releasing hormone (Barry, 1979; King et al., 1982; Barry et al., 1985).

Furthermore, the VMH provides sparse-to-moderate projections to other hypothalamic nuclei like the dorsomedial and ventral premammillary nuclei that provide dense inputs to the parvicellular neurosecretory region (Ter Horst and Luiten, 1986; Canteras et al., 1992b; Thompson et al., 1992).

Apart from these intrahypothalamic routes, another possible way for the VMH to influence the release of prolactin and gonadotropins is by way of its projection to the A13 dopaminergic cell group located in the medial zona incerta, a cell group that has been implicated in mechanisms controlling of the release of these hormones (McKenzie et al., 1984; Sanghera et al., 1991; Wilson et al., 1991).
Although the VMH may influence the neuroendocrine system in many ways, our anatomical data implies that the nucleus most likely plays only an indirect role in this control.
On the other hand, fibers passing through or near the VMH may be directly involved (for example, fibers on their way to the median eminence).

It has been reported that VMH lesions interfere with diurnal rhythms of plasma corticosterone levels and food intake (Balagura and Devenport, 1970; Bernardis, 1973; Bellinger et al., 1976; Egawa et al., 1991), which are also known to be influenced by the suprachiasmatic nucleus, the endogenous circadian rhythm generator (see Watts et al., 1987, for references).

Although the VMH sends only a small number of fibers to end within the borders of the suprachiasmatic nucleus, it does project massively to the subparaventricular zone (including the perisuprachiasmatic region), which apparently plays a pivotal role in relaying to effector circuitry circadian patterns of neuronal activity generated in the suprachiasmatic nucleus itself (Watts et al., 1987).

In addition, massive lesions centered in (but not restricted to) the VMH, but not in the suprachiasmatic nucleus, abolish the prefeeding corticosterone peak in rats whose access to food is restricted to a fixed time of day (Krieger et al., 1977; Krieger, 1980).
Thus, it is possible that a projection from the VMH to the subparaventricular zone may influence the corticosterone rhythm entrained by restricted feeding.

Interestingly, a 24 hour rhythm of multiple-unit activity has been demonstrated in the VMH of animals on a restricted feeding schedule, and this rhythm is said to persist after lesions of the suprachiasmatic nucleus.
However, the VMH, unlike the suprachiasmatic nucleus, does not appear to contain an independently driven circadian oscillator (Inouye, 1983).

There is general agreement that the VMH plays an important role in the expression of feeding (Hetherington and Ranson, 1942; Brooks et al., 1946; Perkins et al., 1981; Shimizu et al., 1987; Miiiano and Myers, 1991), defensive (Fuchs et al., 1985a,b), and feminine copulatory (see Pfaff, 1980; Cohen and Pfaff, 1992) behaviors.
A number of studies also indicate that the VMH modulates autonomic responses associated with these behaviors.

Thus, apart from regulating food intake, the VMH may also play a role in diet-induced thermogenesis by influencing sympathetic drive to brown adipose tissue (Perkins et al., 1981; Niijima et al., 1984; Holt et al., 1987; Le Feuvre et al., 1991).

In addition, the VMH may influence 1) the secretion of insulin and glucagon; 2) hepatic glucose production, peripheral glucose utilization, and free fatty acid mobilization (Hales and Kennedy, 1964; Tucker et al., 1964; Frohman and Bernardis, 1971; Goldman et al., 1972; Takahashi and Shirnazu, 1981); and 3) gastric secretion (Ridley and Brooks, 1965; Costal1 et al., 1986; Gunion and Tache, 1987; Gunion et al., 1990).
The VMH is also thought to participate in the cardiovascular responses that accompany defensive behavior (Djojosugito et al., 1970; Takeuchi and Manning, 1973; Tan and Dampney, 1983).
Finally, the VMH may also play a role in antinociceptive mechanisms (Takeshige et al., 1992).

Interestingly, the periaqueductal gray has also been clearly implicated in similar functions, including control of the lordosis reflex (see Pfaff, 1980; Cohen and Pfaff, 1992), defensive behavior (see Bandler et al., 1991; Depaulis et al., 19921, caloric intake (Skultety, 19661, and analgesia (Mayer, 1979).
It has been well documented that projections from the VMH to the periaqueductal gray are important for the expression of the lordosis reflex (see Pfaff, 1980; Cohen and Pfaff, 1992).

The execution of this response is dependent on hormonal influences (i.e., estradiol andlor estradiol and progesterone) in the VMH, where binding tends to be restricted to the VMHvl (see opening paragraphs).
Therefore, the ventrolateral part of the VMH appears to be important for expression of the lordosis reflex.

In this context, it is important to point out that, unlike other parts of the nucleus, the VMHvl projects densely to the medial preoptic nucleus and peripeduncular area, which have also been implicated in modulating the probability of lordotic 1978; L6pez and Carrer, 1985; responses (see Carrer, Swanson 1987).

Therefore, direct projections from the VMH to the periaqueductal gray should play an important role in the somatic and autonomic defensive responses observed following electrical stimulation of the VNIH.

Recent studies have shown a differential pattern of defensive responses following chemical stimulation of different parts of the periaqueductal gray (see Depaulis et al., 1992), and it is thus important to emphasize the topographic organization of projections we observed from the VMH to the periaqueductal gray.

Furthermore, previous studies have suggested that ascending projections from the VMH to regions as far rostra1 as the septum are also important for the expression of defensive behavior following electrical stimulation of the VMH (Fuchs et al., 1985a,b).

It is therefore interesting that a majority of these hypothalamic and septal targets also provide substantial inputs to the periaqueductal gray (Morrell et al., 1981; Beitz, 1982; Marchand and Hagino, 1983; Meller and Dennis, 1986; Rizvi et al., 1992).

Thus, to understand the role of the VMH in the expression of defensive behavior, direct projections to the periaqueductal gray, along with indirect pathways relayed through other hypothalamic and septal targets of the VMH, must be taken into account, bearing in mind that all of these projections are topographically organized, so that different parts of the VMH may subserve different aspects of these behaviors.

As was noted above, the VMH is thought to influence a variety of autonomic responses associated with the control of metabolism, brown adipose tissue thermogenesis, gastric secretion, and the cardiovascular system.

Although the periaqueductal gray probably relays information from the VMH to autonomic motoneurons (see Luiten et al., 1987), Swanson and Kuypers (1980) reported that a very small number of cells within the VMH may project directly to the spinal cord (possibly to the intermediolateral cell column), and the nucleus also projects to other targets known to provide direct inputs to both sympathetic and parasympathetic preganglionic cell groups.

Thus, the VMH appears to innervate the posterior hypothalamic nucleus, the subparafascicular nucleus, and the retrochiasmatic area, all of which contain at least a few neurons that project to the dorsal vagal complex and/or the spinal cord, presumably to the intermediolateral cell column.

However, it is not clear where in the spinal cord most of these fibers actually end, and the number of cells that project to lower autonomic centers in these regions is quite small (see Swanson, 1987; Moriizumi and Hattori, 1992).

In addition, the VMH sends rather substantial projections to lateral regions of the BST and the medial part of the central nucleus of the amygdala, both of which are known to provide direct, massive inputs to the dorsal vagal complex (Sofroniew, 1983; Holstege et al., 1985; see Price et al., 1987, for reviews).
Finally, the projection to Barrington s nucleus should also be considered a possible way for the VMH to influence sacral parasympathetic preganglionic neurons (Loewy et al., 1979).

Because the VMH may participate in the expression of several types of god-oriented behavior, it seems likely that the nucleus plays a role in the integration of appropriately adaptive somatomotor responses.

Involvement of the VMH in somatomotor control is suggested by experiments in which injection of the hydrogel of a water-absorbent polymer into the nucleus induced bursts of running that could be inhibited either by surgical isolation of the nucleus or by the local injection of GABA, implicating neuronal projections from theVMH (Yokawa et, al., 1989,1990).

Aside from the periaqueductal gray, which is clearly involved in integrating a variety of somatomotor responses (see Bandler et al., 1991; Depaulis et al., 19921, the VMH may also have access to other circuitry thought to be involved in mediating locomotor aspects of certain goal-directed behaviors.
A central position in this circuitry is occupied by the nucleus accumbens and a subpallidal region that includes the substantia innominata and lateral preoptic area.

These regions send massive descending projections to the zona incerta, substantia nigra, ventral tegmental area, and pedunculopontine nucleus, and are thus thought to influence spinal pattern generators for locomotor behavior (for reviews see Swanson and Mogenson, 1981; Mogenson et al., 1983; Swanson et al., 1987a).

Apart from sending direct inputs to the substantia innominata, the VMH appears to provide a substantial input to other structures like the BST, medial preoptic area, and anterior hypothalamic nucleus, which, in turn, project heavily to the subpallidal region (Swanson and Cowan, 1979; Simerly and Swanson, 1988; Risold et al., 1994).

According to our results, the VMH also sends a light direct projection to the nucleus accumbens, and, in this context, it is important to recall that the VMH may also provide a substantial input to the paraventricular and parataenial nuclei of the thalamus, which, in turn, project massively to the nucleus accumbens (see Berendse and Groenewegen, 1990).

Considering how many possible ways the VMH may influence both the nucleus accumbens and subpallidal region, it seems plausible that it must be involved in modulating the general level of activity in this circuitry, in sharp contrast, for instance, to cortical inputs to the nucleus accumbens and other parts of the striatum that are likely to convey more specific information to somatomotor control systems.

Because the VMH seems to play an important role in the expression of several goal-oriented behaviors, it is important to point out that the nucleus may also have access to circuits implicated in emotion-related learning and memory.

Thus, the central and lateral nuclei of the amygdala, the principal amygdaloid targets of the VMH, have been implicated in circuitry involved in associative learning processes with an emotional component, where the central nucleus appears to play a pivotal role in mediating somatic and visceral responses through its projections to brainstem areas, whereas the lateral nucleus appears to be an important site for the integration of sensory information reaching the amygdala (LeDoux, 1987; LeDoux et al., 1990).

Furthermore, the VMH has direct as well as indirect access to the hippocampal formation, known to be critically involved in neural mechanisms underlying short-term memory and the more permanent consolidation of particular events in other regions of the cortex (see Swanson et al., 1987b, for references).

Thus, apart from sparse direct projections to the entorhinal area, one possible way for the VMH to access the hippocampal formation is through the midline thalamic nuclei, particularly the nucleus reuniens, which is thought to modulate transmission through the hippocampal system (Herkenham, 1978; Wouterlood et al., 1990; Wouterlood, 1991).

In addition to the midline thalamic nuclei, it is worth recalling that other targets of the VMH project to the hippocampal formation, including the lateral nucleus of the amygdala, the piriform area and endopiriform nucleus, and insular areas (see Swanson et the perirhinal and agranular al., 198713).
Much less is known about the functional significance of the TU.

However, in view of the observations that 1) its projections are virtually identical to those of the VMH; 2) its medial border lies immediately adjacent to the ventrolatera1 border of the VMHvl, interrupting the capsule of the VMH; and 3) a subpopulation of its neurons concentrate estrogen, like neurons in the adjacent VMHvl, it is tempting to suggest that the TU may eventually come to be viewed most appropriately as a lateral component of the VMH itself.

In addition, at least four regions that innervate the VMH or its capsule also generate terminal fields restricted to the TU; these regions include the posterior and posterolateral cortical nuclei of the amygdala (Canteras et al., 1992a1, the ventral subiculum (Canteras and Swanson, 1992b), and the lateral part of the medial preoptic nucleus (Simerly and Swanson, 1988).
At present, the feature that serves to distinguish most clearly between the VMHdm, VMHv1, and TU is the ratio of androgen and estrogen receptor mRNAs found within them (Simerly et al., 1990).
Thus, androgen receptor predominates in the VMHdm, both receptors are abundant in the VMHv1, and estrogen receptor predominates in the TU.

This feature, combined with slightly different patterns of inputs and outputs, may underlie somewhat different roles for these cell groups in sexually dimorphic aspects of reproductive, defensive, and ingestive behaviors along with the visceral responses accompanying them.
